III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section Sufficiency of staff.
Description (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff are allowing Youth A to be bullied and hit by other youth.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed over the phone on 5/21/2025.
Complainant did not provide additional information.
Youth A was interviewed with MDHHS Worker at the facility
on 5/9/2025. Youth A stated he has a terrible and sometimes
good relationship with the other youth. He stated there was a
youth, he could not recall who, that used to say mean things to
him and would hit him every day. He recalled telling an unknown
staff member what happened, and that staff member handled it by
speaking to the other, unknown youth. He reported this youth is no
longer at the facility. He stated a couple days ago, a youth, he
could not recall who, was trying to hit him, but staff intervened. He
stated this staff blocked the youth from hitting him. Youth A did not
recall who the staff member was. He reported he always has a
staff member with him because he is on one-on-one supervision.
Youth A did not report any other youth are bullying or hitting him.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed with MDHHS
Worker at the facility on 5/9/2025. CA does not have any
knowledge of staff allowing Youth A to be bullied or hit by other
youth. There are no reports of Youth A being bullied or hit by other
youth.
Staff 1 was interviewed with MDHHS worker at the facility on
5/12/2025. Staff 1 reported she has not observed staff allowing
Youth A to be hit or bullied by other youth. Staff 1 stated Youth A
does the bullying and Youth A consistently verbally and physically
assaults staff. Staff 1 stated she’s had to restrain Youth A several
times due to him assaulting youth or staff.
Staff 2 was interviewed with MDHHS worker at the facility on
5/12/2025. Staff 2 reported Youth A is often the aggressor. He has
not observed Youth A being bullied and hit by other youth or staff
allowing it to occur. Staff 2 reported Youth A yells, screams and
2

curses at everyone. He stated the youth can be friends one
minute and then arguing the next. He stated he has witnessed
Youth A get into physical fights with other youth but they are fights
that Youth A started. He stated staff will restrain if youth are
fighting or re-direct and manage the situation of the environment.
He stated staff will separate both youth so the issue does not
further escalate.
Staff 3 was interviewed over the phone on 6/6/2025. Staff 3
stated he has not observed Youth A being bulled or hit by other
youth or staff allowing it to happen. He stated Youth A is usually
the one that is punching, hitting, kicking or spitting on staff. When
Youth A assaults staff, staff will use the child control restraint.
Staff always try to calm Youth A down by re-directing him or letting
him go for a walk while staff follow closely behind him.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
6/25/2025. Youth B stated he has never witnessed or heard any
youth bullying Youth A. He stated Youth A is always calling other
youth and staff bad names when he is upset. He stated he has
witnessed Youth A fighting staff and staff will put him into a
standing restraint to calm him down. Youth B laughed at the
allegation as he said it is funny because Youth A is disrespectful
and bullies other youth.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
6/25/2025. He stated he has never witnessed or heard any youth
bullying Youth A. Youth C stated Youth A is often the bully, but
Youth A directs much of his anger towards staff. Youth C stated
Youth A calls other youth “black bitches” or “bitches” when he
becomes upset. He stated staff will intervene by trying to calm him
down.
Documentation Reviewed:
• There are no incident reports regarding Youth A and
other youth bullying him.
• Youth A MiSACWIS Incident Reports dated from
3/28/2025 – 7/2/2025: Youth A has 35 incidents of Youth A
verbally and physically assaulting youth and staff.
• Line of Sight Policy: Line of sight is described as having
the ability to reasonably visually distinguish and recognize
individuals. During all events staff are to remain in ratio and
maintain line of sight when in direct supervision of the
youth.
3

Analysis The facility was found in compliance as per interviews with staff

allowing Youth A to be bullied or hit by youth.
Conclusion Violation Not Established

• Behavior Support and Management Policy:
Wolverine Human Services Behavior Support and
Management plan places paramount importance on the
safety of clients, as well as, the staff. All staff are certified
in Crisis Prevention Institute (CPI), Non-Violent Crisis
Intervention. The course is taught by certified instructors
and all employees must demonstrate competency in skills
and application of principles to obtain the certification.
The philosophy of this program is twofold. First, the focus
is to provide immediate emotional and environmental
support to clients in crisis so that stress and the risk for
violence are reduced. Secondly, the focus is to teach
clients more constructive, effective ways of dealing with
stress and painful feelings so that the future risk for
violence is reduced. Staff members are re-certified yearly
to ensure competency standards are maintained. The
various principles of CPI are reinforced during training
opportunities. Wolverine Human Services is committed to
maintaining a culture of respect for all persons, clients and
staff alike. WHS values a trauma informed setting and
milieu in residential programming. This policy is for the
purpose of ensuring that when a non-violent physical
intervention is required, that the manner in which it is used
is in strict adherence with applicable state and federal
requirements governing its use.
B. Definitions:
12

Non-violent – Restrictive intervention is defined a as
staff member’s use of physical control to contain a client’s
acute physical behavior. a physical hold to maximize safety
and minimize harm, i.e. any behavior that is likely to result
in physical injury or imminent risk of physical harm of the
client, other clients, staff members, or others. These
interventions are non-violent and are to be used in such a
manner as to not be hostile or injurious. All non-violent
physical interventions at Wolverine Human Services will
follow the principles established by the CPI curriculum.
Approved techniques for Restrictive intervention include:
o Standing – low – medium - high
o Seated - low – medium - high
o Team Control – high level
o Children Control position. – low – medium - high
2. Non-Violent Restrictive Intervention Report (WHS
Incident Report) is defined as the required documentation
completed whenever any of the above defined forms of
non-violent physical interventions are used. Staff
document the incident immediately following conclusion of
the incident for supervisory review and response as
appropriate.
4. Behavior Notification is defined as the required
documentation completed whenever an incident or event
occurs which is out of the ordinary and the use of a non-
violent physical intervention did not occur. This report is to
accurately describe the incident and context within which it
occurred. The forms are region specific.
C. The Use of Non-Violent Physical Restriction:
Non-violent physical restrictions are never to be used as a
form of punishment, discipline, ensuring compliance,
demonstrating authority, or retaliation. They are only used
to protect client or others from unanticipated or severely
aggressive behavior that places them at serious threat of
violence or injury if no immediate intervention occurs. The
steps leading up to non-violent physical restriction must
follow the teachings and principles of the CPI curriculum.
(Refer to CPI Student Workbook, Edition 2.)
Non-violent physical interventions may only be initiated by
staff that have successfully completed the written
component, the Life Space Interview evaluation and
demonstrated competency in the physical components.
They are only to be in place long enough to end the threat
of serious physical harm.
Staff members are to continuously monitor the client to
ensure safety and assess for any harmful health or
13

psychological reactions. If a client being physically
controlled appears to be in physical distress, immediate
notification of the Program Manager or designee is to
occur, and the nonviolent physical intervention technique is
discontinued. Immediate medical evaluation is required
under these circumstances. In the event a client displays
an altered mental status, immediate notification of Program
Manager or designee is to occur and when it is determined
to be safe the non-violent physical intervention technique is
discontinued.
The use and choice of all non-violent physical interventions
must be guided by a number of factors including the
following:
1. The need to ensure safety of other clients and staff.
2. The size and strength of the client to be restrained.
3. The nature and degree of past violent behavior by
the client.
4. Whether or not the client has a weapon.
5. Physical or health conditions of the client to be
restrained.
6. The client’s Individual Crisis Management Plan
(ICMP).
D. Use of Mechanical Interventions:
1. Mechanical restraints are prohibited for the purposes
of behavior management.
2. Mechanical restraints are prohibited for use on
pregnant clients during labor, delivery, and recovery, to
include leg/ankle shackles, abdominal restraint, secured
wrists behind back, and four-point restraints.
E. Notifications of all Behavior Notifications
Notification will be made to the following individuals
following any non-violent physical intervention and will
include a brief summary of the events that led to the
intervention, actions taken following the restraint, including
medical services rendered, and a plan for debriefing and
how the person notified can participate.
Immediately
On duty site supervisor (YSS)
Lead Supervisor
Program Manager
WHS Case Manager
Site Administrative Staff
Within 6 hours if injury occurred or 12 hours if no
injury
Parent/ guardian, including MCI Superintendent, if
applicable
14

Referring Worker/Court Liaison
Client’s attorney or guardian ad litem

G. Post Incident Debriefing
Following any incident involving non-violent physical
intervention, the site management will ensure that
debriefing and support is offered to the client, the staff
members, and any other persons involved or witness to the
incident. The organization has a formal grievance
procedure in place for the clients that is easy to
understand, assures confidentiality, and is readily
accessible.
Debriefings occurs in a safe, confidential setting as soon as
possible following the incident and includes the client(s)
involved, caregivers, personnel involved, and agency
leadership.
Immediate debriefing of involved personnel and clients
serves to:
Evaluate physical and emotional well-being of client and
staff.
Identify the additional need for counseling, medical care, or
other services related to the incident
Identify precipitating behaviors and modify the clients
service plan or ICMP as appropriate; and facilitate the
person's reentry into routine activities
Debriefing of the client(s) and staff are documented on
agency forms (Staff Post-Incident Debriefing Form for staff
and Life Space Interview for clients) and serves to assess
their current physical and emotional status, the precipitating
events of the incident, evaluation of how the incident was
handled, and necessary changes to procedures and/or
training to avoid future incidents.
